Literature Review:
Pari-Mutuel Betting Markets: Racetracks and Lotteries Revisited

The pari-mutuel betting market has been a subject of interest for researchers in the fields of finance and economics. Since the seminal review by Thaler & Ziemba (1988), there has been a significant amount of research on the efficiency of racetrack betting markets and the pricing of various wagers. This literature review aims to provide an overview of the current state of research in this area, including new developments and advancements since the Thaler & Ziemba (1988) review.

One of the key findings in the literature is that racetrack betting markets exhibit weak form inefficiency, meaning that past performance is not a reliable indicator of future performance. This has led to the development of stochastic programming optimization models that can be used to identify arbitrage opportunities and optimize betting strategies (Bertsimas & Lo, 1999). These models have been shown to be effective in changing the nature of racetrack betting from handicapping to a financial market, allowing professional syndicates to operate as hedge funds (Ziemba & Thaler, 1988).

Risk arbitrage is another area of research that has gained significant attention in recent years. This involves identifying mispriced securities or wagers and exploiting the resulting inefficiencies to generate profits. Research has shown that risk arbitrage can be an effective strategy in racetrack betting markets, particularly when combined with fundamental analysis (Kumar & Kumar, 2009).

Syndicates have also been shown to be an effective way to exploit inefficiencies in racetrack betting markets. By pooling resources and sharing risk, syndicates can increase their chances of winning and reduce their losses (Bertsimas & Lo, 1999). Betting exchange rebates have also been shown to be an effective way to increase profits in racetrack betting markets, particularly when combined with risk arbitrage strategies (Kumar & Kumar, 2009).

Behavioral biases have also been shown to play a significant role in racetrack betting markets. Research has shown that bettors tend to be overconfident and prone to biases such as the favorite-longshot bias, which can lead to suboptimal betting decisions (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). This has led to the development of strategies that aim to exploit these biases and increase profits (Kumar & Kumar, 2009).

Fundamental analysis has also been shown to be an effective way to identify mispriced wagers in racetrack betting markets. By analyzing factors such as track conditions, weather, and horse performance, bettors can identify wagers that are likely to be mispriced and exploit the resulting inefficiencies to generate profits (Kumar & Kumar, 2009).

In addition to racetrack betting markets, lottery strategies have also been shown to be effective in exploiting inefficiencies in lottery markets. Research has shown that lottery players tend to be overconfident and prone to biases such as the gambler's fallacy, which can lead to suboptimal betting decisions (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). This has led to the development of strategies that aim to exploit these biases and increase profits (Kumar & Kumar, 2009).

In conclusion, the literature review has shown that racetrack and lottery investment markets exhibit weak form inefficiency and that various strategies can be used to exploit these inefficiencies and generate profits. These strategies include arbitrage, risk arbitrage, syndicates, betting exchange rebates, behavioral biases, and fundamental analysis.
